specs.what: All styles for both pages. Mobile-first. CSS custom properties. No framework.
sections_to_style: hero (100vh, bg image, overlay, fade-in animation, CTA buttons)
manifesto (dark surface, centered column, gold rules between statements)
virtues (CSS grid 4-col → 2-col tablet → 1-col mobile, card hover border-gold)
founder (2-col grid desktop → 1-col mobile, grayscale avatar)
codex page: header, article grid, article card
utility: .fade-in class (opacity 0 + translateY 20px → visible via JS)

key_rules.founder_avatar: filter: grayscale(100%). width: 300px. aspect-ratio: 1/1. object-fit: cover.
key_rules.cta_primary: background: var(--gold). color: var(--bg). font-family: var(--font-display). padding: 0.85rem 2rem. no border-radius.
key_rules.cta_secondary: background: transparent. color: var(--text). border: 1px solid rgba(245,240,232,0.3). same padding.
key_rules.card_hover: border-color: var(--gold). transition: 200ms. No transform, no shadow — per Elena.
key_rules.section_fade: .fade-in { opacity: 0; transform: translateY(20px); transition: opacity 0.6s ease, transform 0.6s ease; } .fade-in.visible { opacity: 1; transform: none; }

behaviors.nav_scroll: Add class .scrolled to <nav> when window.scrollY > 60. Remove on scroll back up.
behaviors.mobile_nav: Toggle class .open on .nav-menu when .hamburger is clicked. Close on any link click or outside click.
behaviors.fade_in: IntersectionObserver on all .fade-in elements. When threshold 0.15 met, add class .visible. Unobserve after.

specs.js_budget: Under 50 lines total. No libraries. DOMContentLoaded wrapper.

articles.title: The Hardship Hierarchy
articles.excerpt: Not all suffering is equal. The man who treats every inconvenience as a crisis will break under real weight. Learn to rank your trials — and use each one deliberately.

articles.title: Iron Over Pills
articles.excerpt: Modern men are medicated against the symptoms of a life without challenge. The pharmaceutical solution treats the signal, not the source. Here is the antidote.

articles.title: Men Are Rational
articles.excerpt: When the juice stops being worth the squeeze, men stop squeezing. This is not a crisis. It is not apathy. It is logic — and the men calling it a problem are the same ones who removed the incentives.
